pullRequest.body:
In this file we prove the Product Formula for number fields: for any non-zero element `x` of a number field `K`, we have `∏|x|ᵥ=1` where the product runs over the equivalence classes of absoulte values of `K` and the `|⬝|ᵥ` are suitably normalized.

## Main Results
* `NumberField.FinitePlace.prod_eq_inv_abs_norm`: for any non-zero element `x` of a number field `K`, the product `∏|x|ᵥ` of the absolute values of `x` associated to the finite places of `K` is equal to the inverse of the norm of `x`.
* `NumberField.prod_abs_eq_one`: for any non-zero element `x` of a number field `K`, we have `∏|x|ᵥ=1` where the product runs over the equivalence classes of absoulte values of `K`.


---

</details>
I'll have a look over the weekend.

> I didn't really look at the full argument but I feel like parts of it are more painful than they could be. On the other hand getting over the line is definitely the first goal, so thanks a lot for this important start!

Thanks! I am not an expert so I am very happy to learn!

I didn't really look at the full argument but I feel like parts of it are more painful than they could be. On the other hand getting over the line is definitely the first goal, so thanks a lot for this important start!

I didn't really look at the full argument but I feel like parts of it are more painful than they could be. On the other hand getting over the line is definitely the first goal, so thanks a lot for this important start!

```suggestion
  rcases IsFractionRing.div_surjective (A := 𝓞 K) x with ⟨a, b, hb, rfl⟩
```

`bijective_iff_existsUnique` is a very roundabout way to go about this. You have `maximalIdeal_mk` and `mk_maximalIdeal` which are exactly the ingredients to define
```lean
noncomputable def NumberField.FinitePlace.equivHeightOneSpectrum :
    FinitePlace K ≃ HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K) where
  toFun := maximalIdeal
  invFun := mk
  left_inv := mk_maximalIdeal
  right_inv := maximalIdeal_mk
```

(probably this should be in `NumberTheory.NumberField.FinitePlaces`) and then lemmas
like `maximalIdeal_injective` and `maximalIdeal_inj` aren't even really necessary because they're just `(equivHeightOneSpectrum K).injective` and `(equivHeightOneSpectrum K).injective.eq_iff`. Similarly this proof becomes
```lean
  · exact (finprod_eq_of_bijective maximalIdeal (equivHeightOneSpectrum K).bijective
      (fun w ↦ (norm_embedding_eq w (x : K)).symm))
```
We have tons of API for `equiv` so you should use it.

```suggestion
  refine (inv_eq_of_mul_eq_one_left ?_).symm
```
It's less confusing that way

```suggestion
    simp [h_x_nezero]
```
For terminal simps it seems that we're now being encouraged not to squeeze them, because it makes maintaining them harder. Nobody wants to see `not_false_eq_true` anyway :-)

```suggestion
  have h_subs₁ : t₁ ⊆ t₀ := by simp [norm_eq_one_iff_not_mem, t₁, t₀]
```
Why? Is there another approach here?
No, this comment is there to explain what is about to happen...

```suggestion
  have ha : a ≠ 0 := by
    rintro rfl
    simp at h_x_nezero
```

```suggestion
number field `K`, we have `∏ |x|ᵥ=1` where the product runs over the equivalence classes of absolute
```

```suggestion
`K`, the product `∏ |x|ᵥ` of the absolute values of `x` associated to the finite places of `K` is
```

```suggestion
`∏ |x|ᵥ=1`, where the product runs over the equivalence classes of absolute values of `K`.
```
Spaces for readability. (I would also prefer an empty line below the `#` and `##` lines, but this is a matter of taste.)
Maybe say something about how the absolute value is normalized?

```suggestion

open Function Ideal IsDedekindDomain HeightOneSpectrum in
```

```suggestion

open FinitePlace in
```

I suggest separating out the lemmas
```lean
namespace IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum

open NumberField FinitePlace

lemma equivHeightOneSpectrum_symm_apply (v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K)) (x : K) :
    (equivHeightOneSpectrum.symm v) x = ‖embedding v x‖ := by
  have : v = (equivHeightOneSpectrum.symm v).maximalIdeal := by
    show v = equivHeightOneSpectrum (equivHeightOneSpectrum.symm v)
    exact (Equiv.apply_symm_apply _ v).symm
  convert (norm_embedding_eq (equivHeightOneSpectrum.symm v) x).symm

open Ideal in
lemma embedding_mul_absNorm (v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K)) {x : 𝓞 K} (h_x_nezero : x ≠ 0) :
    ‖(embedding v) ↑x‖ * absNorm (v.maxPowDividing (span {x})) = 1 := by
  rw [maxPowDividing, map_pow, Nat.cast_pow, norm_def, vadicAbv_def,
    WithZeroMulInt.toNNReal_neg_apply _
      (v.valuation.ne_zero_iff.mpr (RingOfIntegers.coe_ne_zero_iff.mpr h_x_nezero))]
  push_cast
  rw [← zpow_natCast, ← zpow_add₀ <| mod_cast (zero_lt_one.trans (one_lt_norm v)).ne']
  norm_cast
  rw [zpow_eq_one_iff_right₀ (Nat.cast_nonneg' _) (mod_cast (one_lt_norm v).ne')]
  simp [valuation_eq_intValuationDef, intValuationDef_if_neg, h_x_nezero]

end IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum
```
(between the `variable` and `namespace NumberField` lines). They both look like reasonably useful statements by themselves. Then the proof can be simplified according to the suggestion below.

(There is no need to go via powers with real exponents here.)

```suggestion
  simp only [← finprod_comp_equiv equivHeightOneSpectrum.symm, equivHeightOneSpectrum_symm_apply]
  refine (inv_eq_of_mul_eq_one_left ?_).symm
  norm_cast
  have h_span_nezero : span {x} ≠ 0 := by simp [h_x_nezero]
  rw [Int.abs_eq_natAbs, ← absNorm_span_singleton,
    ← finprod_heightOneSpectrum_factorization h_span_nezero, Int.cast_natCast]
  let t₀ := {v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K) | x ∈ v.asIdeal}
  have h_fin₀ : t₀.Finite := by simp only [← dvd_span_singleton, finite_factors h_span_nezero, t₀]
  let t₁ := (fun v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K) ↦ ‖embedding v x‖).mulSupport
  let t₂ :=
    (fun v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K) ↦ (absNorm (v.maxPowDividing (span {x})) : ℝ)).mulSupport
  have h_fin₁ : t₁.Finite := h_fin₀.subset <| by simp [norm_eq_one_iff_not_mem, t₁, t₀]
  have h_fin₂ : t₂.Finite := by
    refine h_fin₀.subset ?_
    simp only [Set.le_eq_subset, mulSupport_subset_iff, Set.mem_setOf_eq, t₂, t₀,
      maxPowDividing, ← dvd_span_singleton]
    intro v hv
    simp only [map_pow, Nat.cast_pow, ← pow_zero (absNorm v.asIdeal : ℝ)] at hv
    replace hv := fun h ↦ hv (congrArg (HPow.hPow (absNorm v.asIdeal : ℝ)) h)
    classical
    simpa only [imp_false, Associates.count_ne_zero_iff_dvd h_span_nezero (irreducible v)] using hv
  have h_prod : (absNorm (∏ᶠ (v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K)), v.maxPowDividing (span {x})) : ℝ) =
      ∏ᶠ (v : HeightOneSpectrum (𝓞 K)), (absNorm (v.maxPowDividing (span {x})) : ℝ) :=
    ((Nat.castRingHom ℝ).toMonoidHom.comp absNorm.toMonoidHom).map_finprod_of_preimage_one
      (by simp) _
  rw [h_prod, ← finprod_mul_distrib h_fin₁ h_fin₂]
  exact finprod_eq_one_of_forall_eq_one fun v ↦ v.embedding_mul_absNorm h_x_nezero
```

```suggestion
/-- For any non-zero `x` in `K`, the product of `w x`, where `w` runs over `FinitePlace K`, is
```

```suggestion
  rw [← inv_eq_iff_eq_inv, inv_inv_div_inv, ← abs_div]
```

```suggestion
  have hb₀ : ((Algebra.norm ℤ) b : ℝ) ≠ 0 := by simp [hb]
  refine (eq_div_of_mul_eq hb₀ ?_).symm
```
I think this is a bit clearer. (There should be a `MonoidHom.map_div₀`; this would simplify the argument a bit...)

pullRequest.title: feat: the product formula for number fields
